DOC.HEAD: Romanian Princess-Turned-Nun Says Prayers Answered
Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `He was...' to CORRECT style on Antichrist.
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania's Princess Ileana, now a nun at an Orthodox monastery in rural western Pennsylvania, said her homeland was saved ``in the nick of time'' by a revolution she never thought she'd live to see. ``I always believed my prayers would be answered,'' the Rev. Mother Alexandra said Tuesday. The 80-year-old daughter of King Ferdinand and Queen Marie, and great-granddaughter of England's Queen Victoria and Czar Alexander II of Russia, said her European contacts told her ousted President Nicolae Ceausescu had to die. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed by a firing squad Monday following conviction by a secret military tribunal. The former Communist leader and his wife had been captured Saturday, a day after a popular uprising forced him from power. He was denounced as the ``Antichrist'' and accused of killing 60,000 people. ``They said 60,000 is enough ... and it (execution) had to be done because it would have gone on and on and on,'' Mother Alexandra said in a telephone interview from the Orthodox Monastery of the Transfiguration near Ellwood City. ``They had to do it, so they tell me. I personally have no opinion.'' Mother Alexandra's father was king from 1914 until his death in 1927. Her nephew, King Michael, was forced to abdicate by the communists in 1947 and lives in Switzerland. ``I didn't expect the whole thing, I must say. I've lived with it so long. It's been 42 years since I left,'' she said. ``The strength of the country has always been in its peasantry. That's what Ceausescu was destroying. I hope there is enough of them left and enough intellectuals left to be able to build again.'' Princess Ileana was exiled from Romania with the rest of the royal family soon after King Michael's abdication in December 1947. She immigrated with her husband, an archduke of Austria, and their six children to Switzerland and then Argentina before settling in 1950 in the United States. The move ultimately led to divorce. She ended a second marriage to become a postulant, or a candidate for the religious order, in 1961. Six years later, she took her monastic vows and put up a trailer outside Ellwood City to began building an English-speaking monastery for Orthodox women of all ethnic backgrounds. Mother Alexandra said she has spent much of the past week on the telephone with friends and relatives in Europe, keeping abreast of developments and consoling friends of the many who died in the uprising. She said that even with the changes elsewhere in Eastern Europe she did not expect such quick, drastic moves in her homeland. ``Quite honestly, I was feeling very depressed about it,'' she said. ``I thought everybody was doing something but nothing was moving in Romania at all. And suddenly, it blew up.'' Mother Alexandra said she is working with the Romanian Orthodox Episcopate of America in Jackson, Mich., to organize a Save Romania Fund. She also plans a special service at the monastery this week for Romania's dead. She said she would consider returning to Romania ``if I could be of use.''
